trans-unit.source: Quiz module 2 : How does Machine Learning Work?

source.g: Quizz to complete the second module of the AI4T Mooc (objective 1 : acculturation)

Artificial neural networks are inspired by biology, in a rudimentary way : a neuron or rather a computational unit is reduced to combining its inputs by adding values weighted by weights (a bit like the coefficients of the marks in an exam - we speak of linear combination - then transforming the value obtained by setting it, for example, to 0 or almost 0 if the value obtained is low, or to 1 or almost 1 if it is high.
It is the connection of a large number of these units in the form of a network which allows sophisticated calculations to be made.

The weights are the parameters that allow this calculation to be "programmed" and they are adjusted on the data. This is obviously a far cry from true biological models.It is not the data that connect to each other, but the numerical values of the calculations. The resulting algorithms do not correspond to the usual algorithms, which are explicitly programmed in a computer language.
What is an Artificial Neural Network?
A programming technique where the program learns from data
Networked data that communicates with each other
Several "classical" algorithms put together
A mechanism that has nothing to do with biological neurons: it's just a "fashionable" way to name any algorithm
A mechanism loosely inspired by biological neurons: elementary units of computation connected to bring out a complex computation
A mechanism that finely reproduces biological neurons: neurotransmitters, membrane structure, aso

Yes, like the weather, we can predict the future or more accurately some very specific and narrow elements of that future. These predictions are statistical, like election polls before going to the polls, so the values are necessarily defined with some uncertainty.
We don't predict "there's a cat in this picture" but "there's, say, a 90% chance that it's a cat." So it works even if the phenomenon is completely predictive.

And when one uses the reading of stars or cards to predict the future, it is scientifically not "false" (nor "true"!), it is a belief. Besides, "psychics" also use statistics to successfully guess what we want to hear ourselves say: it's easy, most people come to them for heart, money or power worries, and I can, already, predict that things will surely get better as long as you take charge of your life :).
What is a prediction mechanism in artificial intelligence
A mechanism that uses statistical regularities to estimate the probabilities of an unknown phenomenon (present or future)
A mechanism that can see into the stars based on maps an imaginary mechanism, impossible to predict the future
An imaginary mechanism, unable to predict the future
A mechanism that works if and only if the phenomenon is completely predictive
Long before the development of mechanical intelligences, philosophers like Leibnitz, had understood that an automatism would be all the more efficient if it was assigned a very specific task.

There is even a theoretical computer science theorem called the "no free lunch theorem" (one would say "nothing is free") which demonstrates that a learning algorithm which would be capable of learning all possible and imaginable tasks, could only be, then, totally inefficient! In fact, the only rule of operation would be to choose at random, according to this result

Something similar is observed in humans, in particular Asperger's autistics, who develop totally unheard-of skills in a very specific area, to the detriment of a more general development of their cognition - this comparison being purely metaphorical. We humans have general cognitive abilities in contrast to artificial intelligences.

Another profound difference between human and machine intelligence is the fact that the former uses a language with all its richness to develop its thought, in contrast to a machine in which information is represented in the form of a formal language. Humans also use formal languages, for example, musical scores or medical prescriptions, for specific tasks.

It is also known that an artificial intelligence cannot develop autonomously : it cannot, in fact, check its own bugs. For example, a computer program cannot check whether any other program can loop indefinitely or not. This is the "stopping"problem for which it is shown that there will never be such an algorithm. On the other hand, based on statistical properties, these mechanisms can perform extraordinarily well in specific tasks.
What AI is...and What it is not...

trans-unit.source: It develops through a complex non-formal language
It exceeds human performance on specific tasks
It cannot develop independently, not even check its own bugs
It has a limited capacity in a specific area
It can simulate emotions but not feel them
It develops through a formal language
It uses statistics on a large amount of data to learn
It is incarnated in a body

source.g: There is a limit to what artificial intelligences can do.

One can translate a text very easily, but translating a poem or a symbolic text with all its connotations and cultural elements is much more complex! The famous example is that of Edgar Poe's extraordinary stories translated by Charles Baudelaire "with such an exact identification of style and thought, such a faithful and flexible freedom that the translations produce the effect of original works and have all the original perfection of them*". This is typically something that an algorithm will not do.

By contrast, driving a train or landing a plane is safer if done by a machine, yet the pilot is retained to handle unforeseen situations. Conversely, and contrary to much hype, getting an autonomous car to drive in the city is probably a task that will never be done unless we strongly adapt our urban structures.
One can also use an image transformation mechanism to create, from a photo, a picture that statistically resembles a Van Gogh painting. But this, of course, will not fool an expert.

We can finally simulate emotions on a cobot (a robot that interacts with humans), and make humans feel those simulated emotions. This does not, of course, mean that the electronic circuits and mechanical organs feel these emotions.
What can be done today with AI algorithms ?
Translate a text mechanically from one language to another
Automatically generate a painting indistinguishable from a real Van-Gogh painting
Drive a car autonomously in the city
Drive a train or land a plane
Translate a poem from one language to another, taking into account the culture and sensitivity of the people who will read it
A robot that feels emotions
A robot that simulates emotions

trans-unit.source: Similar data are grouped together to understand "its" geography (clustering)
Examples or prototypes are given to identify new data
Feedback is given as a positive (reward) or negative value for learning on each
The mechanism detects regularities in the data, such as the number of parameter
The solution to be found is provided with the data
Complete the content above before moving on.

source.g: Yes, reinforcement learning is the right paradigm as soon as we are in an environment where what enables learning comes in the form of positive feedback (a "reward") or negative feedback:
- a cobot will adapt its operation based on feedback from humans in its environment,
- the parameters of a product (e.g. a coffee) will adjust according to the level of satisfaction that is given,
- at the end of a game, the mechanism will know whether its strategy is supported or challenged.

Similarly our understanding of animal behaviour is akin to reinforcement learning (sometimes referred to as training), we even understand in the brain in what form this mechanism is implemented: dopamine for example is a neurotransmitter that encodes pleasant surprises (unexpected or greater than expected reward) and allows behaviour to be adjusted; The selection of the action is made in the basal ganglia under the cortex, it is computer models used in machine learning that give a fairly accurate account of this functioning.

But no ;) programming a computer in all its generality cannot be done from another algorithm, if only to detect whether the program is going to finish or loop indefinitely, that remains in the realm of intelligence, and therefore in the human realm.
When is it best to use reinforcement learning ?
to program cobots (robots that operate in interaction with humans)
to make good coffee based on consumer satisfaction
to teach an algorithm to win at a game without explicitly programming a strategy
to model the behaviour of an animal at the level of its action selection
to automatically generate any program in Python

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

source.g: Data is a key element of AI. Let's look at some of the ways in which it is collected.

Artificial intelligence needs input data in order to produce output data. We can tap into our personal data, trying to predict one part of our data from another part, but often it is humans who have to "label" the data by hand, to give examples to the machine: this creates a "click industry" with sometimes regrettable abuses.
Where does the data that is used in machine learning systems come from?

Artificial intelligence needs input data in order to produce output data. We can tap into our personal data, trying to predict one part of our data from another part, but often it is humans who have to "label" the data by hand, to give examples to the machine: this creates a "click industry" with sometimes regrettable abuses.

It is impossible to "create" original data from scratch, artificial intelligence does not have that intelligence ;). On the other hand, there are sometimes tricks like semi-supervised learning where data can be created by an external process, or by Generative Adversarial Networks or GAN where one mechanism produces training data for another mechanism, but ... from real data.
They are made automatically and only by the artificial intelligence itself.
They are produced by people who are paid per click and tag thousands of images by hand.
In machine learning systems, there is no longer any need for data.
Our personal data is used as a knowledge base.

The textual contents of Wikipedia are made for humans and not for machines, and no need to recognize the characters (as it is the case if we take a handwritten sheet of paper) they are already in the machines; While analyzing the meaning of a text goes far beyond recognizing the signs of the writing, it is still a research topic. So, yes you have to label the flower images by hand, but this can be done in a participatory way by interested people. It's worth going to the Plantnet project website if you want to see how it works
You have to invent an AI that has to help recognise flowers: what data is needed?
flower data (photos with precision on the place, date, etc.) proposed by people who want to participate, even if there may be wrong answers.
Wikipedia textual content analysed by a character recognition algorithm
hand-labelled images of flowers
